In recognition of its importance in sustaining economic growth and thereby 
helping to reduce poverty, infrastructure development is a key pillar of the 
Government’s  medium-term  development  framework  (MTDF)  for  2005–
2010.  The  MTDF  aims  to  (i)  deliver  more  reliable  and  affordable  power 
supplies  to  industrial,  commercial,  and  household  customers,  meet  the 
increasing  demand  for  electricity,  and  enhance  the  operational  efficiency 
of the power sector; (ii) establish an efficient and well-integrated transport 
and  logistics  system  that  will  facilitate  the  development  of  a  competitive 
economy  by  increasing  access  to  and  the  quality  of  transport  services 
while  reducing  their  cost  and  ensuring  their  safety;  and  (iii)  enhance 
access to drinking water and ensure drinking water security.  
 
Addressing  the  serious  bottlenecks  in  infrastructure  will  require  the 
investment of substantive resources during the MTDF period and beyond. 
Given  the  Government’s  fiscal  situation,  these  investments  cannot  be 
financed  by  the  public  sector  alone,  hence  alternative  approaches  are

Recognizing  that  the  Government  is  aiming  for  substantial  increases  in 
medium-term  growth  rates  supported  by  infrastructure  development,  the 
Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) country strategy and program update 
2006–2008  for  Pakistan  placed  renewed  emphasis  on  infrastructure 
development. As such, the country strategy and program encompasses a 
series  of  interventions  in  the  infrastructure  subsectors  of  (i)  energy; 
(ii) transport,  logistics,  and  communication;  (iii)  irrigation  and  water 
resource development; and (iv) urban development and renewal.   
 
The  proposed  Program  would  help  fill  an  important  gap  in  implementing 
the  Government’s  strategic  agenda  as  articulated  under  the  MTDF  by 
strengthening  the  enabling  environment  for  PPI.  By  doing  so,  the 
operation  will  help  the  Government  to  leverage  more  financial  resources 
into infrastructure by using the private sector as an intermediary. This will 
help fill the gap between the infrastructure that the Government can afford 
and  the  infrastructure  needed  for  economic  development  and  poverty 
reduction as articulated in the MTDF. 
 
Subprogram  1  aims  to  enhance  economic  growth  through  improved 
infrastructure services. The outcome will be enhanced PPI in infrastructure 
investment  and  maintenance  to  reduce  the  Government’s  fiscal  burden 
and  provide  better  infrastructure  services  to  the  population  and  to 
enterprises.  To  achieve  these  objectives,  Subprogram  1  will  address  key 
constraints to PPI by (i) establishing an overall policy, legal, and regulatory 
framework  for  PPI;  and  (ii)  deepening  policy,  legal,  regulatory,  and 
institutional reforms in priority subsectors, including power, highways, and 
water.  
 
Key  constraints  to  PPI  are  (i)  insufficient  institutional  arrangements  for 
building  consensus  between  federal  and  provincial  authorities  on  PPI, 
(ii) weak  institutional  capacity  to  facilitate  PPI,  (iii)  inadequate  legal 
protection for investors, and (iv) lack of standard bidding procedures and 
documents  for  PPI.  To  address  these  constraints,  Subprogram  1  will 
(i) establish  a  comprehensive  PPI  policy  providing  a  coherent  framework 
for PPI, (ii) establish a PPI policy task force, (iii) strengthen the capacity of 
PPI  project-facilitating  state  agencies  to  build  a  strong  pipeline  of  PPI 
projects, (iv) provide a legal and institutional basis for arbitration to protect 
investors,  and  (v)  standardize  bidding  procedures  and  documents  to 
increase transparency. 
 
ADB will support the Government’s PPI policy reforms under Subprogram 
1  by  providing  a  program  loan  of  $400  million  from  the  ordinary  capital 
resources  of  ADB  under  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-
based lending facility. The loan will have a 15-year term, including a grace 
period  of  3  years,  an  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
LIBOR-based  lending  facility,  and  a  commitment  charge  of  0.75%  per 
year,  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  set  forth  in  the  draft  Loan 
Agreement.  Subprogram  2,  which  is  expected  to  require  a  loan  of  $200 
million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, will be presented separately 
and will depend on the progress achieved under Subprogram 1.

The Ministry of Finance will be the executing agency for Subprogram 1. 
 

The  Government  has  established  the  Program  Coordination  Unit  in  the 
Ministry  of  Finance  to  coordinate  program  implementation.  The  Program 
Coordination  Unit  will  cooperate  closely  with  the  PPI  Policy  Task  Force, 
which  comprises  high-level  officials  from  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  the 
Planning  Commission,  and  other  state  bodies  relevant  to  PPI  policy 
reforms and is chaired by the adviser to the prime minister on finance. The 
task  force  is  mandated  to  establish  working  groups  to  advance  specific 
areas of the policy reforms supported under Subprogram 1. The task force 
will be supported by a technical and administrative secretariat. 
 
The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  foreign  exchange  costs  of 
items  produced  and  procured  in  ADB  member  countries,  other  than  the 
items specified in the negative list of ineligible items and imports financed 
by other bilateral and multilateral sources. 
 
The Borrower shall ensure that the local currency funds generated by the 
Subprogram 1 loan shall be used (i) to support the costs of reforms to be 
initiated  and  implemented  under  Subprogram  1,  and  (ii)  to  finance 
expenditures for the general development purposes of the Borrower. 
 
The  Program  will  support  the  Government  in  creating  an  enabling 
environment  for  PPI  rather  than  building  the  needed  infrastructure 
exclusively with public funds. Given its scarcity of financial resources, this 
is the only feasible approach for addressing the mismatch between limited 
supply  and  increasing  demand  for  infrastructure,  thereby  promoting  long-
term economic growth for poverty reduction and directly enhancing access 
by the poor to essential services. 
 
The policies, procedures, standards, and best practices for PPI developed 
under  Subprogram  1  will  (i)  provide  more  planning  certainty  and  legal 
protection  for  potential  investors,  and  (ii)  reduce  the  period  required  for 
project  development  and  closure  of  transactions.  This  will  reduce  costs 
and help mobilize PPI. More transparent, competitive, and fair tenders for 
PPI  projects  will  also  help  attract  more  competitive  private  investors.  All 
these undertakings will, in turn, free up public resources needed to provide 
other public services, including social services. 
 
Pilot  PPI  projects  developed  under  Subprogram  1  will  directly  leverage 
private resources into infrastructure investment and generate opportunities

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  the  Private 
Participation in Infrastructure Program (the Program) in the Islamic Republic of Pakistan, which 
comprises  (i) a  proposed  program  cluster  of  loans  to  develop  an  enabling  environment  for 
private participation in infrastructure (PPI), and (ii) a proposed program loan for Subprogram 1 
of the cluster. The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for supporting the 
Program  and,  if  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  Board  of  Directors  approves  the 
proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT1 

Following  a  foreign  exchange  crisis  in  1998,  Pakistan  has  managed  an  economic 
2. 
turnaround.  Despite  regional  instability,  the  economy  appears  to  be  on  a  strong  growth 
trajectory: growth of gross domestic product (GDP) increased sharply from 1.8% in fiscal year 
(FY) 2001 to 8.4% in FY2005; the Pakistan rupee has stabilized against the US dollar; the fiscal 
deficit fell from 5.4% of GDP in FY2000 to 3.3% in FY2005; and the external debt-GDP ratio had 
dropped from 49.5% at the end of June 2001 to 31% by June 2005.  

3. 
This impressive turnaround was achieved through prudent fiscal and monetary policies in 
combination  with  structural  reforms,  including  deregulation  and  privatization.  The  reforms  were 
guided by the Government’s recognition that the production of goods and the provision of services 
are best carried out in the private sector, and that the private sector should be the main engine for 
growth  and  employment  generation.  Deregulation  and  privatization,  particularly  in  banking, 
telecommunications,  and  the  oil  and  gas  sectors,  has  had  a  positive  effect  on  the  economy. 
Following privatization, these three sectors, together with manufacturing, have expanded rapidly 
and  attracted  substantial  foreign  investment.  In  FY2004  and  FY2005,  completed  privatization 
transactions amounted to the equivalent of $0.5 billion and $0.7 billion, respectively. In the first 10 
months  of  FY2006,  $3.6  billion  of  Government  equity  was  sold.  As  a  result,  the  quality  and 
outreach of banking and telecommunications services has improved substantially. 

4. 
Nevertheless, recent challenges underline the need to continue prudent macroeconomic 
management. While consumer price inflation averaged 3.9% in FY2001–FY2004, it accelerated 
sharply from 4.6% in FY2004 to 9.3% in FY2005, mainly because of higher prices for food, oil, 
and housing. The cost of raising capital has also increased with the increase in interest rates for 
6-month  Government  securities  by  5.86  percentage  points  during  FY2005.  Given  inflationary 
expectations,  long-term  debt  markets  remain  largely  illiquid.  The  country’s  current  account 
balance, after registering substantial surpluses since 2001, turned into a deficit of $1.8 billion in 
FY2005, or 1.6% of GDP (excluding official transfers). This amount more than tripled in FY2006 
to  $4.4  billion  or  4.4%  of  GDP.  These  developments  pose  risks  to  the  country’s  medium-term 
economic outlook. 

5. 
There  is  also  a  need  to  continue  structural  reforms.  Underinvestment  in  new 
infrastructure  and  poor  maintenance  of  existing  infrastructure  resulting  from  low  development 
expenditure  in  the  1980s  and  1990s  have  created  infrastructural  bottlenecks  that  are 
undermining  Pakistan’s  economic  growth.  While  the  Government  has  managed  to  expand 
development expenditures since 2000, the macroeconomic risks outlined earlier point to a need 
to contain Government expenditures. Under these conditions, and to meet the growing demand 
for  infrastructure  and  utilities,  the  Government  has  recognized  the  need  to  leverage  private

III. 

THE INFRASTRUCTURE AND UTILITIES SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, 

AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Sector Description and Performance 

6. 
Despite ongoing reforms, the mismatch between limited supply and increasing demand 
for  infrastructure  and  utilities  is  particularly  severe  in  three  key  subsectors  of  the  economy: 
power, transport, and water. Appendix 1 presents a sector analysis. 

1. 

Power Subsector 

7. 
Power subsector reforms foresee gradual corporatization of the state-owned Water and 
Power  Development  Authority  into  power  generating,  transmission,  and  distribution  entities. 
Notable progress has been made in implementing these reforms, including the establishment of 
21  independent  power  producers,  the  corporatization  and  partial  privatization  of  the  Karachi 
Electricity Supply Company, and the establishment of the National Transmission and Dispatch 
Company.  The  National  Electric  Power  Regulatory  Authority  has  been  established  to  regulate 
and supervise the sector. This regulatory authority issues licenses to generation, transmission, 
and distribution companies and determines the tariff for each distribution company. The Ministry 
of  Water  and  Power  implements  the  Government’s  power  policies,  together  with  the  Private 
Power and Infrastructure Board (PPIB). To facilitate private investment, PPIB serves as a one-
stop shop for PPI in the subsector.  

8. 
Despite these reforms and a substantial increase in energy generation, the subsector is 
still  characterized  by  insufficient  generation  capacity  and  operational  inefficiencies,  including 
transmission  and  distributions  losses  (estimated  at  25%).  Operational  inefficiencies  lead  to 
financial  losses  for  the  Water  and  Power  Development  Authority  and  the  Karachi  Electricity 
Supply  Company.  Furthermore,  about  45%  of  the  population  lacks  access  to  electricity  and 
enterprises lose a significant share of their revenues because of power outages.  

9. 
To  address  these  issues  and  support  an  annual  GDP  growth  target  of  6  to  8%, 
substantive  public  and  private  investment  is  required.  The  government’s  medium-term 
development framework (MTDF) for 2005–20102 estimates that $8 billion of private investment 
will be needed in the power sector during the MTDF period.  

2. 

Transport Subsector 

10. 
Roads. Road transport accounts for 91% of passenger traffic and 95% of freight traffic. 
A  2005  survey  indicates  that  47%  of  national  highways  and  a  large  proportion  of  provincial 
roads are in poor to very poor condition. As a result, travel time along the north–south Lahore–
Karachi  transport  corridor,  which  serves  80%  of  Pakistan’s  land  trade  and  95%  of  its  external 
trade, takes twice as long as travel along an equivalent-length highway in Europe or East Asia. 
In  addition,  despite  significant  competition  in  road  freight  transport  services,  freight  rates  are 
substantially  higher  than  in  Brazil  or  India,  for  instance,  and  the  same  as  in  the  People’s 
Republic  of  China,  where  service  quality  is  higher.  The  existing  transport  capacity  cannot

11. 
The  National  Highway  Authority  (NHA)  under  the  Ministry  of  Communications  is  the 
custodian  of  Pakistan’s  national  highways,  which  carry  an  estimated  90%  of  commercial  road 
traffic.  Efforts  have  been  made  to  commercialize  NHA.  By  introducing  a  fee-for-service 
approach,  NHA  has  managed  to  increase  its  direct  revenues;  however,  annual  revenues 
collected are about PRs3.6 billion, whereas maintenance requirements alone are PRs5 billion to 
PRs10  billion  per  year.  As  such,  substantial  public  and  private  investment  funds  have  to  be 
mobilized for road maintenance and development. The MTDF estimates that $2 billion of private 
investment  in  transport  and  communication  (including  railways  and  ports,  but  excluding 
telecommunications)  will  be  required  over  the  MTDF  period.  Few  instances  of  private 
investment in roads have materialized so far. 

12. 
Railways.  State-owned  Pakistan  Railways  now  carries  less  than  5%  of  freight  traffic. 
Railway  infrastructure  and  the  rolling  stock  have  deteriorated  because  of  a  lack  of  investment 
and maintenance. Pakistan Railways is overstaffed, operates at a loss, and requires about $340 
million  in  subsidies  per  year.  Pakistan  Railways  has  been  unable  to  adapt  to  the  increasing 
demand for door-to-door transport services and has failed to introduce up-to-date logistics. Rail 
freight  transport  takes  two  to  three  times  longer  than  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China.  The 
board  of  Pakistan  Railways  was  restructured  in  2000  and  more  responsibility  was  given  to 
managers of the main business lines. As a result, commercial performance has been enhanced. 
In  addition,  a  financial  advisory  team  has  drawn  up  measures  for  modernizing  Pakistan 
Railways.  Subsequently,  the  Government  decided  to  corporatize  Pakistan  Railways.  In  2002, 
with  a  view  to  supporting  PPI  in  railways,  legislation  was  approved  for  establishing  a  rail 
regulatory authority, but this authority has yet to be established. 

13. 
Ports.  Pakistan  has  two  operational  overseas  ports:  Karachi  Port,  which  is  run  by  the 
Karachi  Port  Trust,  and  Qasim  Port,  which  is  run  by  the  Port  Qasim  Authority.  Ninety-five 
percent  of  Pakistan’s  foreign  trade  passes  through  these  two  ports.  Despite  recent  efficiency 
gains,  which  were  due  mainly  to  commercialization,  Pakistan’s  ports  are  still  expensive  by 
international standards, for example, estimates indicate that freight handling costs are 1.5 times 
those in Mumbai and 4.5 times those in Colombo. The Government has embarked on a policy of 
implementing the landlord model3 for its oversea ports to facilitate PPI. Small PPI projects have 
been  undertaken  in  the  port  sector  on  a  build-operate-transfer  basis,  but  these  have  not 
involved significant funding. 

3. 

Water Subsector 

14. 
The  underdevelopment  of  water  and  sanitation  facilities  impairs  economic  growth  and 
aggravates poverty. Only 39% of the population has access to piped water and most people are 
exposed  to  unsafe  and  polluted  water.  As  little  as  42%  of  the  population  has  access  to 
sanitation facilities. With the exception of a few big cities, sewerage facilities do not exist, which 
causes  serious  health  problems.  Massive  investment  is  required  to  upgrade  water  and 
sanitation  services:  the  cost  of  upgrading  water  infrastructure  alone  is  estimated  to  range

1. 

Enabling Environment 

a. 

PPI Policy Framework 

23. 
Pakistan’s  experience  with  PPI  since  the  early  1990s  underlines  the  importance  of 
reaching equitable agreements with private sector investors that carefully balance investors’ and 
public interests while taking into account such issues as concentration of market power, pricing, 
service quality, protection of property and of users’ rights, and management of foreign exchange 
risks. This experience has helped develop a policy and regulatory framework and best practice 
for PPI in those sectors in which projects were primarily focused, namely, telecommunications, 
oil  and  gas,  and  some  areas  of  the  power  subsector.  However,  no  such  framework  exists  for 
PPI in other areas of the power subsector, such as renewable energy generation, and in other 
subsectors,  including  transport  and  water  supply  and  sanitation.  Thus  private  investors  face 
high risks and incur substantial costs when developing projects in these sectors. 

 

 6 

 

This issue is compounded by complexities across various levels of government that blur 
24. 
the assignment of ownership, accountability, and regulatory responsibility in relation to service 
delivery  functions  and  legal  enforcement  powers.  Even  though  the  Ordinance  on  Local 
Government  (2001)  assigns  accountability  for  provincial  and  local  roads,  water,  and  other 
utilities to local governments, in practice, agencies at a higher level still control many services. 
This result in additional uncertainty, risks, and costs for private investors, which has effectively 
prevented  them  from  participating in  subsectors  that  are mainly  under  provincial or  communal 
jurisdiction. 

25. 
Private  investors  require  firm  legal  protection  for  their  investments  and  a  well-defined 
environment  within  which  to  cooperate.  Concession  agreements  between  public  and  private 
investors do exist in the form of concession notifications, which are enforceable under current 
tax and customs legislation; however, there is no legal basis that defines general standards for 
concession agreements. This is an impediment for PPI, particularly in areas where investments 
do not generate high revenues in the short to medium term.  

26.  While the overall legal and regulatory framework for environmental safeguards for public 
and  private  infrastructure  projects  has  been  established,6  the  Government  has  yet  to  adopt 
environmental  protection  policies.  Similarly,  social  safeguard  policies  have  yet  to  be  adopted.  
As  such,  investors  face  considerable  uncertainty  relating  to  the  environmental  and  social 
safeguard policies and standards with which they have to comply.  

b. 

Viability of Infrastructure Projects  

27.  Many infrastructure projects, particularly those in the water subsector, are economically 
justifiable,  but  fall  short  of  financial  viability.  As  a  result,  these  projects  fail  to  attract  private 
investors.  The  lack  of  financial  viability  usually  arises  from  long  gestation  periods  and  the 
inability  to  increase  user  charges  to  commercial  levels.  Infrastructure  projects  also  frequently 
involve  externalities  that  are  not  adequately  captured  in  direct  financial  returns  to  the  project 
sponsors.  Unless  financial  assistance  in  the  form  of  a  capital  grant  is  provided  to  make  the 
projects viable, private investors are unlikely to participate in these projects. 

c. 

Dispute Resolution 

28.  Weaknesses  in  the  court  system  constrain  contract  enforcement.  This  deters  investors 
from entering into PPI arrangements, which are contractual by definition. While judicial reforms 
are  ongoing,  addressing  weaknesses  in  the  judiciary  may  take  a  long  time.7  Moreover,  even 
within  a  court  system  that  is  efficient  overall,  contract  enforcement  through  the  courts  can  be 
costly and time-consuming. A need to establish alternative dispute resolution mechanisms, such 
as  mediation  or  conciliation  for  smaller  technical  disputes  or  arbitration  for  larger  disputes, 
therefore exists. Alternative dispute resolution modalities permit the disputing parties to choose 
their own arbiters. As this enables the involvement of technical experts, it is often the mode of 
dispute  resolution  preferred  by  investors  in  complex  commercial  cases,  even  in  industrial 
economies.

2. 

Sector-Specific Issues 

a. 

Power Subsector 

31.  While  the  corporatization  of  the  power  sector  operations  of  the  Water  and  Power 
Development Authority  has been legally completed, its divestiture continues to be slower than 
anticipated. This limits opportunities for private investment. While decisions to privatize the two 
remaining  state-owned  gas  companies  have  been  made,  a  privatization  tender  has  yet  to  be 
announced. 

32. 
Predictability  and  risk  mitigation  are  crucial  success  factors  for  PPI.  Private  investors 
require a framework that can assure them of a market-driven return at reasonable levels of risk, 
while  at  the  same  time,  consumers  demand  adequate  service  quality  at  an  affordable  cost. 
These  preconditions  are  difficult  to  establish,  as  the  terms  of  project  agreements,  as  well  as 
tendering  arrangements,  are  usually  complex,  involving  detailed  legal  and  contractual 
agreements that clearly set forth the risks, rewards, and obligations of various parties. Reaching 
mutually  acceptable  and  sustainable  solutions  is  more  difficult,  time-consuming,  and  costly 
without  a  clear  policy  that  sets  the  framework  for  tender  procedures  and  contractual 
arrangements.  Unfortunately,  no  such  policy  framework  exists  for  PPI  in  renewable  energy 
generation,  despite  the  high  priority  given  by  the  Government  to  private  participation  in  this 
particular subsector. 

33. 
As the Government’s one-stop shop for PPI in the power subsector, PPIB has started to 
make  substantial  contributions  to  attracting  private  investment,  but  is  constrained  by  weak 
capacity.  PPIB  currently  has  34  professional  staff  for  processing  45  new  PPI  projects  and 
supervising  the  implementation  of  16  ongoing  projects.  Capacities  need  strengthening  in  the 
areas  of  (i)  the  technical  know-how  needed  to  review  prefeasibility  studies  and  safeguard 
assessments, and (ii) the legal know-how needed to negotiate and implement power purchase 
agreements and facilitate dispute resolution. These weaknesses tend to substantially slow down 
the  processing  of  PPI  projects  and/or  lead  to  agreements  that  are  difficult  to  implement.  The 
problem is aggravated by the absence of standard bidding procedures and model contracts for 
projects  in  renewable  energy  generation.  As  a result,  tender  documents  and  negotiations  with 
investors are frequently ad hoc.
